Award.AwardTitle: Thirteenth International Congress on Mathematical Education (ICME-13) Travel Grant

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the participation of 55 U.S. K-12 mathematics teachers or supervisors, graduate students, community college/university mathematics teachers, mathematicians, mathematics teacher educators and mathematics education researchers to attend the Thirteenth International Congress for Mathematical Education (ICME-13) to be held in Hamburg, Germany, July 24-31, 2016. The project will also prepare an educational status report (called the Fact Book) for the United States. The research team will report on the state of U.S. mathematics education in 2016, through a Fact Book that builds from those published for ICMEs 9, 10, 11, and 12.

Through participation in the conference, American math educators will interact with mathematics educators from many countries and learn about their current math education practices concerning curriculum development, the use of technology in learning mathematics, strategies for reaching all students, teacher education and ongoing teacher professional development. The project is supported major national mathematics research and professional societies including the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators, United States National Commission on Mathematical Instruction, Mathematical Association of America, American Mathematical Society and American Mathematical Association of Two Year Colleges. Participants will disseminate information and resources from the conference through these mathematics organizations, math education journals, and social media.

The Discovery Research K-12 (DRK-12) program seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models, and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. This conference will advance the understanding of the U.S mathematics community regarding current international research and development in mathematics education, addressing the Teaching and Learning strands of the DRK-12 program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ICME -13 Travel Grant supported 64 mathematics educators (K-12 teachers, school personnel, community college instructors, university mathematics educators, mathematics education researchers, graduate students and mathematicians) to attend the Thirteenth International Congress on Mathematical Education  (ICME-13) held in Hamburg, Germany on July 24-31, 2016. Attending the Congress enabled awardees to learn what is happening in mathematics education across the world (e.g., a seeming shift from whether technology should be used in classrooms to teach mathematics to how technology can be used to maximize student learning); to interact with leading researchers in the international mathematics education community (through presentations, socializing and discussions in Topic Study Groups), and to sharpen and inform their own work. Awardees noted that many of the problems we have in mathematics education in the U.S. are similar to those of other countries and considered how research related to these problemsmight help us better understand them and offer possible solutions (e.g., how best to serve special needs students). The Steering Committee for the grant consisted of representatives from major US mathematics associations: Mathematics Association of America, American Mathematical Society, American Mathematics Association of Two Year Colleges, United States National Commission on Mathematics Instruction, National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, and a member at large.  A major product of the grant is the booklet on the status of mathematics education in the United States.  Mathematics Education in the United States, 2013: A Capsule Summary Fact Book Written for ICME 13(Dossey, Halvorsen & McCrone, 2016). https://www.nctm.org/uploadedFiles/About/MathEdInUS2016.pdf 

Intellectual merit. The experience at ICME-13 served to advance and spread knowledge and understanding of international educational practice and research findings among practitioners and researchers in the United States. Many of the awardees described how attending the Congress enhanced their understanding of international issues and practices of educators and researchers. Those associated with mathematics education researcher found that the discussions and interactions gave them a better sense of direction for their own work. Awardees who were K-12 teachers were introduced to mathematics education research and were able to think about how the results affected their own classroom practices. Awardees who were associated with supervision and curriculum in K-12 schools gained insights into professional development approaches and new ways of managing effective mathematics instruction. At the same time, the awardees were able to contribute ideas from U.S. practices, perspectives, and reforms to the international community through interaction with other participants and the dissemination of the Fact Book, an invaluable resource with specific details about the U.S. educational system.

Broader Impact. ICME-13 engaged the awardees in thinking about mathematics education research and practice from a wide variety of perspectives and in reflecting on how this knowledge could be used to make a difference in the US.  Because the awardees represented such a comprehensive set of mathematics educators, dissemination efforts spanned the spectrum of mathematics education communities in the United States as awardees shared experiences and findings in their interactions with colleagues and through articles and conference presentations. For many awardees, such collaborations helped situate research in a more general context, enhancing the infrastructure for research in mathematics education. Many of the plenary and invited speakers as well as the Topic Study Groups called attention to issues of equity and access across the world in ways that can be useful to those in the US community. The travel grant increased the number and diversity of the U.S. mathematics education community attending the congress, enabling classroom teachers, school mathematics personnel, and university mathematicians to attend, educators who would not normally see themselves as part of an international congress on mathematics education. 

 

Many connections initiated at ICME-13 by awardees have been nurtured and developed since the Congress, and the results have had an impact on research projects, on education programs and schools. For example, on a large scale, the Director of Mathematics (K-12) for one of the largest city school districts in the U.S. has used the connections he made at ICME to implement changes in curriculum and professional development for his teachers that resulted in policies, practices, and mindsets that, in turn, led to a renewed enthusiasm for authentic problem solving by his teachers and improvement in the district's state assessment results. On an individual scale, a young middle school teacher made contacts at ICME that allowed her to spend a semester in another country studying how they approach learning mathematics. In the words of one awardee, “this travel grant creates an amazing opportunity for many people in the mathematics education community to come together and expand their knowledge in relation to mathematics teaching and learning.”
